title: How to Store Popcorn So It Lasts Longer

steps.title: Pop a batch of popcorn and don't season it.
steps.content: Pop a batch of popcorn and don't season it. You can pop kernels on the stove or in the microwave, but don't drizzle the popcorn with butter, sprinkle it with salt, or add flavorings. These can make your popcorn soggy or chewy. If you want to eat healthier, prepare your popcorn with water instead of oil.

steps.title: Let the popcorn cool completely.
steps.content: Let the popcorn cool completely. If you put hot or warm popcorn into a storage container, you'll trap moisture in the container that can make the popcorn become soggy. Ensure that the popcorn is completely cooled before you store it. [1] X Research source Popcorn doesn't take very long to cool. If you're in a hurry, you can spread it out on baking sheets to cool faster.

steps.title: Pack the popcorn into an airtight container.
steps.content: Pack the popcorn into an airtight container. Once the popcorn has cooled, put it into a glass or plastic container. Try not to use a container that's too large or the popcorn will stale faster. If you can, fill the container to the top so there's not as much air in it. If you don't have a jar or rigid storage container, use a sealable plastic bag. Remove all of the air before closing the bag.

steps.title: Store the popcorn at room temperature for up to 1 to 2 weeks.
steps.content: Store the popcorn at room temperature for up to 1 to 2 weeks. If you haven't added salt, butter, or seasoning to the popcorn, it will keep for at least 1 week. Avoid refrigerating the popcorn because this will introduce moisture that can make the popcorn stale. [2] X Research source If you're storing leftover store bought popcorn that you made, check it every few days to see if it's still fresh. Since store bought popcorn is already covered in flavoring, it may become chewy within a few days.

steps.title: Flavor the popcorn
steps.content: Flavor the popcorn just before you eat it. For classic popcorn, toss it with melted butter and salt. If you're feeling more adventurous, melt a little honey with the butter before you drizzle it over. To make savory and spicy popcorn, sprinkle a little chili powder and nutritional yeast over it. The nutritional yeast will give the popcorn a slightly cheesy flavor. [3] X Research source If you don't mind messy popcorn, you can mix the popcorn with caramel or chocolate sauce. To make your seasoned popcorn healthier, use herbal condiments, balsamic vinegar, pickles, or peppers instead of butter, sweeteners, and oils.

steps.title: Preheat the oven to 250 째F (121 째C) and spread the popcorn on a sheet.
steps.content: Preheat the oven to 250 째F (121 째C) and spread the popcorn on a sheet. Get out a rimmed baking sheet so the popcorn won't slide off it. Then, put as much stale popcorn as you like on it. [4] X Research source Arrange the popcorn so it's in a single layer.

steps.title: Heat the popcorn for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Heat the popcorn for 5 minutes. Put the baking sheet into the preheated oven and leave it so it crisps up. You can check the popcorn after 5 minutes to see if it's not soggy or chewy anymore. [5] X Research source If the popcorn is still a little stale, heat it for 1 more minute and check it again.

steps.title: Season the popcorn before you eat it.
steps.content: Season the popcorn before you eat it. If your popcorn is plain, toss it with melted butter and salt or your choice of seasonings. You could sprinkle cheesy powder, curry powder, or cinnamon sugar, for example. [6] X Research source Avoid storing the popcorn once you season it since it'll make the popcorn become soggy again.

steps.title: Pour the oil into a heavy pan and add 2 popcorn kernels.
steps.content: Pour the oil into a heavy pan and add 2 popcorn kernels. Place the heavy pan on the stove and pour 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of canola or vegetable oil into it. Put 2 of the popcorn kernels into the pan and put the lid on. [7] X Research source If you use a pan with a glass lid, you'll be able to see when the kernels pop. If you don't have a glass lid, you'll need to listen for the kernels to pop.

steps.title: Turn the burner to medium-high and wait for a kernel to pop.
steps.content: Turn the burner to medium-high and wait for a kernel to pop. You'll know the oil is hot enough when you see or hear at least 1 of the kernels pop. Avoid frequently lifting the lid to check the kernels because heat will escape from the pan. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Add 1/2 cup (105 g) of popcorn kernels and put the lid back on the pan.
steps.content: Add 1/2 cup (105 g) of popcorn kernels and put the lid back on the pan. Carefully lift the lid and add the kernels. Then, swirl the pan gently so the kernels are coated in the oil and put the lid back on. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Shake the pan over the burner for 2 to 4 minutes so all of the kernels pop.
steps.content: Shake the pan over the burner for 2 to 4 minutes so all of the kernels pop. Swirl the pan gently to keep the kernels moving so they don't burn. You'll hear the kernels begin to pop within 1 to 2 minutes. Then, it will take another 1 to 2 minutes for all of the kernels to pop. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the pan when you hear 3 seconds between each pop.
steps.content: Remove the pan when you hear 3 seconds between each pop. You shouldn't hear very many kernels sliding around the pan if you give it a gentle shake. The popping should also slow down once most of the kernels have popped. Turn off the burner when you hear 1 pop about every 3 seconds. [11] X Research source Look out for pieces of popcorn that might pop out of the pan as you remove it.
